title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.13.40 | 17-10-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya
Chaksharunmi Ritam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Namao Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadhadhara Srivasa Adi Gaurabhakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Narayanam Namaskritya
Naram Chaiva Narottamam Deveem Saraswateem
Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Rayet
In this session we will be discussing from the 40th
and the 41st verses of the 13th chapter
of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
The 40th verse is as follows
Karanadhara Ivaapare Bhagavan Paradarsha Kaha
Athababhase Bhagavan Narado Munisattamaha
The meaning of this verse is
You are like a captain of a ship in a great ocean
and you can direct us
to our destination.
Thus addressed the godly personality Devarshi Narada
greatest of the philosopher devotees began to speak.
So the background for this 40th verse is
that Dhritarashtra has left the palace after hearing the
strong instructions of Vidura.
Vidura, Dhritarashtra and Gandhari all have left the palace.
And Yudhishthira the next day morning is doing his daily morning duties as a pious householder.
So he went to pay respects to Dhritarashtra and he didn't find Dhritarashtra in his usual place.
Then immediately he inquired from Sanjaya, Dhritarashtra's secretary,
Where is Dhritarashtra, my uncle?
So Sanjaya said,
I don't know.
I don't know where he's gone
I have no idea.
Then Yudhishthira began to worry
whether
because
Dhritarashtra and Gandhari had lost all
their sons
and they were very much aggrieved because we were all here.
aggrieved because of the great loss in the battle of Kurukshetra all their 100
sons were killed and their grandsons sons and grandsons everyone was killed in
the battle of Kurukshetra so because he was so very much aggrieved did he leave
the palace to go and drown himself in the river Ganga that was what Yudhishthira
was so much concerned worried in fact Yudhishthira wanted to take care of his
uncle and aunt that they should be comforted when they have undergone such
a huge loss in the last days so he was taking good care actually but suddenly
when they disappeared he began to worry what happened why did they where did they
go and
where have they gone so as he was worrying suddenly Narada appeared in the
palace of Yudhishthira and as soon as Narada came Yudhishthira began to
inquire from Narada and he explained that my uncles and aunt have gone I do
not know where they have gone kindly
tell me what should I do now so Yudhishthira is describing Narada as a
captain of a ship in a great ocean in this analogy is very important for us to
understand that if somebody is I'm going in a ship and is in the middle of the coast
the ocean if every side they look they'll only see water they'll see only
water there'll be no sight of any land in the middle of the great ocean big
ocean there will be no sight of any land then only the captain who knows how to
navigate the ship based on of course nowadays they have modern equipment but
formerly they used to have maps and using the maps and the compass the
direction which they should go they would actually steer the ship in the
ocean and take it from one place where they start shore of the ocean one
place where they start shore of the ocean one
place where they start shore of the ocean one
place where they start shore of the ocean one particular land mark to another
particular land mark to another
particular land mark to another country or another place in the other
country or another place in the other
country or another place in the other side of the ocean so only a captain
side of the ocean so only a captain
side of the ocean so only a captain who's experienced who has got these maps
who's experienced who has got these maps
who's experienced who has got these maps who knows how to how to use the maps to
who knows how to how to use the maps to
who knows how to how to use the maps to steer the ship only such a person can
steer the ship only such a person can
steer the ship only such a person can help the
help the
to reach the destination, the designated place they are supposed to go, they wish to go, they desire to go.
Similarly, Yudhishthira is now lost. He doesn't know where his uncle and aunt are.
But Narada Muni is actually a great philosopher devotee as it will be explained in the, as it is mentioned here.
Narada Munisattamaha, he is the greatest among the philosopher devotees.
So he is like a captain of a ship.
So he is like a captain of a ship.
He is like a captain of a ship in the great ocean.
And Yudhishthira Maharaj is requesting Narada, you please direct us to our destination.
And when Devarshi Narada, the greatest of the philosopher devotees,
the godly personality, he is the greatest of the devotees, pure devotees.
And he is also a philosopher, he is also a great personality,
the greatest of the personalities, such personalities.
And when Narada is addressed by Yudhishthira, he began to speak.
And that will come in the next few verses.
So in the purport Srila Prabhupada says something about Narada.
There are different types of philosophers and the greatest of all of them are those who have seen the personality of Godhead
and have surrendered themselves in the transcendental loving service of the Lord.
And to see the Supreme Lord is not an ordinary thing.
The Lord is completely spiritual.
And not only is he a spiritual personality, but he is also the unlimited Supreme personality.
So one has to first of all become spiritually situated to be able to see or perceive
or realize what is spirit.
And then go beyond this, beyond perceiving spirit,
to be able to perceive or see the Supreme Spirit, the unlimited Supreme Lord.
Both of these are distinct qualifications.
Both of these require distinct qualifications.
Both of these require distinct qualifications.
It's not that anybody and everybody can just either see spirit or ultimately be able to see even the Supreme Spirit.
That is the personality of Godhead.
And after seeing the Supreme Lord, one has to surrender in transcendental loving service.
This is what Krishna explains in the Bhagavad Gita.
This is what Krishna explains in the Bhagavad Gita.
He says,
tad viddhi pranipatena pariprasnena sevaya upadekshanti te jnanam jnaninah tatva-darshinah
Tatva-darshinah means one who has seen the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
And jnaninah, one is full of knowledge about who is the Supreme Lord
and what is the relationship,
what is the relationship of everyone with the Supreme Lord,
and how one can situate himself or herself in the proper position of one's relationship
by surrendering to the Supreme Lord in transcendental loving service.
This surrender is not for any material purpose.
It is not for any other purpose other than to render loving devotional service to the Lord.
That is our actual constitutional position.
So Narada Muni is one such personality who has seen the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
It is described in the earlier chapter how Narada had darshan of the Lord.
Then he realized the Lord.
Then he became situated as a totally surrendered devotee of the Lord.
And after situating himself in that way,
he is simply traveling and preaching to everyone
to help them to get out of this material existence
and reinstate themselves in their original position as pure devotee of the Supreme Lord.
So Narada Muni has now come to actually help Yudhishthira
understand the destination or the future of his uncles and aunt.
So among all such pure devotees of the Lord,
because Lord has many pure devotees like Narada,
Devarishi Narada is the chief.
Narada Munisattamaha.
And therefore he has been described herein as the greatest of all philosopher devotees.
Now even among devotees there are different kinds of devotees.
So who is a philosopher devotee?
That Prabhupada explains,
unless one has become a sufficiently learned philosopher
by hearing the Vedanta philosophy from a bona fide spiritual master,
one cannot be a learned philosopher devotee.
So to know the philosophy of Vedanta.
Vedanta means the conclusion of the Vedas.
And what is the conclusion of the Vedas?
Vedaischa sarvair ahameva vedyam.
Krishna is the goal of all Vedas, Vedic knowledge.
So Narada is such a
a devotee
who has
become sufficiently learned philosopher by hearing the Vedanta philosophy
from the Bhaktivedantas
in his previous life.
And he has become realized.
He followed the instructions
to realize that subject matter
after hearing.
And he had darshan of the Lord.
And he became situated in his
transcendental relationship
as the pure devotee
engaged in transcendental loving service of the Lord.
So therefore Narada Muni
is actually the proper qualified person to guide
somebody like Yudhishtira.
So Prabhupada says one must be very faithful,
learned and renounced.
Otherwise one cannot be a pure devotee.
It's not possible to be a pure devotee
unless one is very faithful.
Bhakti begins with faith.
And that faith has to be developed.
And then one has to become learned
in the science of Krishna consciousness.
Science of Bhakti.
And one has to become renounced.
Completely free from all material attachments.
100% pure.
That's called 100% pure.
Without these qualifications
one cannot be a pure devotee of the Supreme Lord.
And such a pure devotee
is qualified
to help anybody
cross this ocean of ignorance
and reach
the destination
of the shelter of the lotus feet
of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Krishna.
And it is also explained here by Prabhupada
Devarshi Narada used to visit the palace of the Pandavas
because the Pandavas are pure devotees themselves.
And Devarshi Narada used to visit them
and was always ready to give them
good counsel whenever needed.
Of course, Yudhishthira as a pure devotee himself
he is capable of
knowing from directly the Supreme Lord
because he is always engaged in the service of the Lord.
But he is playing the part
of a Kshatriya
who always seeks
the direction of a Brahmana
or a pure devotee
saint, saintly person.
So therefore he is enquiring from Narada.
I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
